Award.AwardTitle: Systems-Level Predictions of Electron Flows in TCE-Dechlorinating, Dehalococcoides Containing Microbial Communities Using Modeling and Emerging Molecular Biology Tools

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1336709
Lisa Alvarez-Cohen
University of California Berkeley

Groundwater contamination by chlorinated solvents is an important problem at thousands of sites within the United States and worldwide. In situ bioremediation of chlorinated ethene-contaminated groundwater involves the biostimulation of indigenous Dehalococcoides bacteria and/or bioaugmentation using Dehalococcoides-containing cultures to completely reduce perchloroethene and trichloroethene to non-toxic ethene. Because these bacteria exhibit specific restrictive metabolic requirements for substrates and cofactors that can be supplied by supportive microorganisms through diverse networks of metabolic interdependencies, this project seeks to deliver systems-level predictions of interspecies electron and metabolite exchange networks that shape the structural and functional robustness of Dehalococcoides-containing microbial communities. Using a combination of engineered control of cultures in continuous-flow bioreactor systems, TCE dechlorination biokinetic modeling and high-throughput, community-level genomic analysis, this research will develop mechanistic, systems-level models under groundwater plume-relevant conditions (i.e., continuous flow with low concentrations of chlorinated ethenes) to optimize and proactively control dechlorination processes under a range of environmental scenarios, leading to a better understanding and predictive control of bioremediation processes.

Groundwater contamination by chlorinated solvents (for example, degreasing fluids and dry-cleaning agents) is an important problem at thousands of sites within the United States and worldwide. Fortunately, a type of naturally-occurring bacteria are capable of biodegrading these contaminants when they are stimulated to grow to high enough population densities, in a process called "in situ bioremediation." These bacteria live in complex microbial communities that provide many of the factors needed by the bacteria to survive and biodegrade the solvents. This project takes a systems-level approach to understanding the interactions within these microbial communities to develop an integrated picture of how complex degrading communities operate and respond to different environmental stressors. This understanding will be captured in predictive models that will be useful for environmental scientists and bioremediation practitioners to evaluate and optimize cleanup strategies for chlorinated solvents, and to provide guidance for strategies to manipulate microbial communities in the field. This project will also support science outreach activities for multiple education levels to stimulate interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics through (co-)curricular learning, tutoring and training services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcome report: Systems-Level Predictions of Electron Flows in TCE-Dechlorinating, Dehalococcoides-Containing Microbial Communities Using Modeling and Emerging Molecular Biology Tools (Grant No. CBET1336709, 7/13-12/16, $340,000).

 

Groundwater in the U.S. serves millions of people as their primary drinking water source, accounting for major water withdrawals by public supply systems. Trichloroethene (TCE), recently classified as a “known human carcinogen” by the National Institutes of Health, along with its daughter products dichloroethene (DCE) and vinyl chloride (VC), are commonly detected groundwater contaminants. In-situ bioremediation using Dehalococcoides mccartyi, the only known organism capable of completely detoxifying TCE, represents an important process applied to groundwater contaminated with chlorinated solvents.

 

In this CBET research project, the Alvarez-Cohen laboratory developed fundamental understanding and predictive models aimed to proactively control and reduce the uncertainty associated with in-situ bioremediation processes. D. mccartyi was previously reported to exhibit more robust growth and higher dechlorination capacities in functionally diverse microbial communities than in pure cultures. Therefore, the first objective of the project was to develop models to characterize the complex interactions among the different members of TCE-bioremediating microbial communities. We constructed simplified consortia containing D. mccartyi and used the developed models to simulate the metabolite exchange and electron flows in the defined consortia that represent the crucial syntrophic interactions in TCE-bioremediating microbial communities. We also investigated the molecular responses and electron flow changes in these syntrophic consortia under various typical environmental factors, and the consequent effects on TCE detoxification. In addition, we successfully established an anaerobic, completely mixed flow reactor (CMFR) and operated it to investigate the community-level metabolite and electron flows in a TCE-detoxifying enrichment culture. Finally, we accomplished our last objective by using cutting-edge sequencing and metagenomic analyses on the CMFR community to elucidate the community structure and functions crucial to TCE bioremediation. In addition to proposed objectives, this award also made extended contribution to relevant studies in the Alvarez-Cohen laboratory in understanding metabolite exchanges in TCE-bioremediating microbial communities, such as vitamin-B12 related molecules, as well as carbon monoxide and formate. This award also contributed to the development of a fluorescence-activated cell sorting method in the Alvarez-Cohen laboratory to perform genomics and transcriptomics analysis on the key TCE-dechlorinating microorganism without isolation.   

This award contributed to the training of five graduate students, three postdocs, and two research scientists, and involved collaborations with researchers at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, USGS California Water Science Center, and the University of Oklahoma. Personnel supported by this grant include Dr. Xinwei Mao (Asst. Prof., Stony Brook University), Dr. Yujie Men (Asst. Prof., University of Illinoi), Dr. Ke Yu (Asst. Prof., Peking University), Dr. Weiqin Zhuang (Sr. Lect., University of Auckland), Dr. Stephanie Jones, (Res. Sci., Industrial Microbes), Dr. Tong Liu (Res. Sci., Illumina), and Mr. Mohan Sun (graduate student, UC, Berkeley). One thrust of scientific outreach for this project was achieved by involving an undergraduate student, Alexandra Polasko (graduate student, UCLA) in research meetings and manuscript writing, learning microbiology and molecular biology skills, and creating, monitoring, and analyzing several of the experiments performed for this project. A second thrust of scientific outreach was achieved by the involvement of graduate students (Xinwei Mao and Mohan Sun) in teaching as they served as graduate student instructors for a graduate-level course in environment biological processes taught by the PI. The kinetic analyses taught in the course, CE 211B, were based upon those required for this research. The GSIs developed expert-level understanding of the principles of enzyme and microbial kinetic through completion of this research, which helped their effectively communicate these concepts, while providing examples of current applications to students in the course.
